content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hi @Nireda : as already mentioned bellow ...
-> l’m OK with your Contribution :-) !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Puzzle is easy and fun, making it a good fit for Clash of code.
nice game

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle! You can do far simpler in Python 3 though:

```
from datetime import datetime

n = int(input())
file_names = [input() for _ in range(n)]
file_dates = [datetime.strptime(input(), "%d-%m-%Y") for _ in range(n)]

for _, file_name in sorted(zip(file_dates, file_names)):
    print(file_name)
```

I passed the review to ready to publish as everyone seems ok with the actual version of this Clash of Code. 

Don't hesitate to validate the game if it's okay for you, or let me know if you need anything before approving.

First time I published a game here, I firstly wrote my solution in javascript but it seems to be in python 3 now (and work well).

Does other contributors can change or wrote solution ?

It's not a problem in itself, just want to know what the process about this.

> If multiple files have the same date, you should then sort them in alphabetical order (case-insensitive).

But your test "More files" requires the sorting to be case sensitive. And the corresponding validator doesn't actually check case sensitivity since the 3 files with the same date (Integer, rhoncus, sit) are sorted the same both ways.
pls make the file name and dates separated in one line. can use space, slash, comma, or pipe as separators

Goal
* Suggest to delete "[[N]]" for simplicity.

* Your expected output shows the files from oldest to newest, but Goal section states "from newest to oldest". Seems that the statement is wrong.

* Please add "in alphabetical order".

* Please mention whether the sorting by file name should be done in a case-sensitive way or case-insensitive way.

Input
* Please format all line numbers in <<bold>>, e.g. "<<Line 1>>".

* Please change "Line 2" *and* "Line 3" to "<<Next [[N]] lines>>".

* Please delete ", seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "data.txt mission.txt account.xls dissertation.docx"".

* Please change ", seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "20-12-2023 21-12-2023 21-12-2023 18-09-2012"" to "in the same order as [[files]], and in the format of [[DD]]{{-}}[[MM]]{{-}}[[YYYY]] where [[DD]] is the day, [[MM]] the month and [[YYYY]] the year".

Output
* Please change "Line 1" to "<<[[N]] lines>>".

* Please change "seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "data.txt mission.txt account.xls dissertation.docx"" to "one file per line".

Constraints
* Please delete the constraint.

* Please add "[[files]] consist of English letters and {{.}} only."

Thanks.

Goal
* Suggest to delete "[[N]]" for simplicity.
- No : If I erase [[N]] then I don't know how to write the loop to read the files and dates.

* Your expected output shows the files from oldest to newest, but Goal section states "from newest to oldest". Seems that the statement is wrong.
- Yes : statement change to "from oldest to newest".

* Please add "in alphabetical order".
- Yes : added.

* Please mention whether the sorting by file name should be done in a case-sensitive way or case-insensitive way.
- Yes : "case-insensitived" added.

Input
* Please format all line numbers in <<bold>>, e.g. "<<Line 1>>".
- Yes : Text in blod done.

* Please change "Line 2" *and* "Line 3" to "<<Next [[N]] lines>>".
- Yes : Lines changes as <<Next [[N]] lines>>

* Please delete ", seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "data.txt mission.txt account.xls dissertation.docx"".
- Yes : indeed I didn't make inputs that way in the end.

* Please change ", seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "20-12-2023 21-12-2023 21-12-2023 18-09-2012"" to "in the same order as [[files]], and in the format of [[DD]]{{-}}[[MM]]{{-}}[[YYYY]] where [[DD]] is the day, [[MM]] the month and [[YYYY]] the year".
- Yes : indeed I didn't make inputs that way in the end.

- To make it more clear I changer "files" and "dates" to "file" and "date"

Output
* Please change "Line 1" to "<<[[N]] lines>>".
-Yes : done.

* Please change "seperated each one by a space.
Ex : "data.txt mission.txt account.xls dissertation.docx"" to "one file per line".
- Yes : done.

Constraints
* Please delete the constraint.
- No : Why do you want me to remove this constraint ? Isn't it usefull to help the player and avoid confusion ?

* Please add "[[files]] consist of English letters and {{.}} only."
- Yes : Indeed, it would better like this. Done.

Thanks.

No : I admit it's a good way to propose inputs, but I'm not sure that it change that much the game. It make it clearer in the statement by seperating them.

Thanks for the feedback ^^

Thanks for the feedback.

As I want to keep the exercice simple I changed the goal to case sensitive. Also I changed the test case "more files" which wasn't really valuable for players. Instead I created a test for case sensitivity.

Let me know if it's better like this.

Hi Jp, thank you for the feedback and the solution proposition !

I passed the review to ready to publish as everyone seems ok with the actual version of this Clash of Code. 

Don't hesitate to validate the game if it's okay for you ;)

After reaching certain conditions, a player gains editor rights and can edit contributions (including the solution). Although not required, an editor should have a sufficient reason to do the editing and leave a comment here stating any major changes made.

More details here:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/approval-process
Thank you ^^

Thank you ! ^^
If you consider it good enough, don't hesitate to approve the game. I'm trying to do an achievement and it would be very helpfull.
Thanks for the information !
Perfect, thanks!
Thanks for the feedback ! ^^
Thank you for your detailed feedback too but I cannot see the changes made as you claimed in your comment. Maybe you haven't saved them?

Arf, forgot to upload I guess :'(
I'll change it again tommorow then.
It should be good now ;)

Thank you for following up.

Output
* Please delete "next".

Constraints
* Please change "files" to "file" for consistency.
Done for both, thanks.
